Award.AwardTitle: Revolutionary and Efficient Synthesis of Cyclic Polymers
Award.AbstractNarration:
With thia award, the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Division of Chemistry is supporting Professors Adam Veige and Brent Sumerlin of the University of Florida to synthesize and characterize polymers that are cyclic and to establish the differerences between these polymers and their linear analogs.Plastics are often comprised of long chain-like molecules called polymers. Plastics are ubiquitous in modern life and in part are responsible for the current high standard and quality of life enjoyed by industrialized nations. Polymers have many different topologies (shapes), but most commonly they are long linear chains. Accessing this new class of polymers and determining their unique properties may create new opportunities for the development of functional materials. Through participating in this cross-disciplinary project, graduate and undergraduate students acquire a diverse set of advanced technical skills for modern inorganic and polymer synthesis and for characterization.

The properties of polymers are, in part, dictated by their chain ends. Cyclic polymers inherently do not have chain ends, and as a consequence, unique physical properties arise. Investigating cyclic polymers remains a challenge even after many decades. Thus, a longstanding challenge in polymer chemistry is to synthesize cyclic polymers efficiently, with diverse compositions, high purity, high molecular weights, and from readily available monomers. This proposal addresses the challenge of synthesizing pure cyclic polymers by employing new catalyst technology developed at the University of Florida. The project involves the synthesis of the first examples of macrocyclic polyenes with high molecular weights. Of particular interest is the synthesis of the first example of cyclic polypropylene and to examine its tacticity. Another important target is cyclic polyacetylene. The parent linear polyacetylene, when doped, remains one of the highest conducting polymers known, though it has limited use since it is unstable in air and intractable. It is one of the aims of this project to investigate how the conductive properties, solubility, and stability differ for the cyclic version. Facilitated access to cyclic analogs of well-known linear polymers provides a convenient method to investigate fundamental structure-property relationships.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Revolutionary and Efficient Synthesis of Cyclic Polymers

Objectives: 1. Synthesize and study the stability and solubility of cyclic polyacetylene

                    2. Synthesize and characterize cyclic versions of common commodity polymers

Overview:

Intellectual Merit: Cyclic polymers inherently do not have chain ends, and as a consequence they demonstrate unique physical properties compared to their linear analogs. Despite decades of research, the efficient synthesis of commercially relevant cyclic polymers, free of linear impurities, and derived from readily available feedstocks was not known. Ring closing of large chains requires high dilution to reach completion, and chain elongation, rather than chain closing, inevitably leads to linear byproducts that are difficult to remove. These challenges limit the large-scale preparation of cyclic polymers. Thus, a longstanding general challenge in polymer chemistry is to synthesize cyclic polymers efficiently, with diverse compositions, high purity, high molecular weights, and from readily available monomers. The important outcome from this project is the successful synthesis of commercially relevant cyclic polymers in high yields from alkynes. For example, one of the most useful materials in our modern world is polypropylene. A significant positive outcome from this project is the successful synthesis and characterization of the first example of cyclic polypropylene. Another commercially relevant polymer is the highly transparent polymethylpentene. Using UF catalyst technology, cyclic polymethylpentene was synthesized and its properties compared to the commercial sample. The cyclic polymer exhibited similarly high transparency but had the added benefit of a much higher glass transition temperature as a consequence of the cyclic topology. Finally, a historically significant polymer is polyacetylene. When doped it is one of the best semi-conducting organic materials known. During the course of this project conditions were found to co-polymerize acetylene and other alkynes to produce soluble and cyclic versions of polyacetylene that have metallic properties.    

Broader Impacts: This proposal provided a platform for training the next generation of highly skilled chemists. Student scientists in the Veige research group received hands-on training in modern inorganic/organometallic chemistry to meet the demands of an increasingly specialized technological workplace. Students in the Sumerlin group learned the physical, analytical, and synthetic techniques of polymer chemistry. This unique opportunity to collaborate between a Catalysis group and a Polymer group enhanced the educational outcomes for the students involved in the project. The scientific broader impacts are significant. By demonstrating the efficient synthesis of commercially relevant cyclic polymers, it is now reasonable to expect further development of these materials to exploit their unique properties. Potential applications include improved wear resistance, improved viscosity, and flexible semi-conducting materials.

 


Last Modified: 12/13/2018
Modified by: Adam S Veige
